docs.title: Welcome to CodeBake
docs.text:
Your Guide to AI-Native Project Management

We're so glad you're here! This documentation is designed to help you get the most out of CodeBake, the project management platform built for the way modern development teams work.

docs.title: 📚 Where to Start
docs.text:
• Getting Started - Jump right in! Set up your account and create your first project.
  • Core Concepts - Learn how we organize things: accounts, projects, phases, and tasks.
  • MCP Tools - The magic part: connect your AI assistant to automate your workflow.

docs.title: What is CodeBake?
docs.text: CodeBake is a project management platform built specifically for developers who work with AI. We know that switching between your code editor and a separate project tracker breaks your flow. That's why we built CodeBake—to bring intelligent project management directly into your development workflow.

docs.title: Why You'll Love It
docs.text:
🤖 No More Busywork Connect your favorite AI assistant (like AugmentCode, Cursor, or Claude Desktop) using the Model Context Protocol (MCP). Your AI handles the status updates for you, so you can stay in your flow and never have to manually move a ticket again.

👀 Total Transparency Project managers and clients can see exactly what's happening at any time with our Activity Summaries. No more "what's the status?" meetings—it's all right there.

🤝 Bring Everyone Along Add unlimited guests to your project for free. Give your clients and stakeholders a front-row seat to view status and add issues, keeping everyone in the loop without the friction.

💻 It's Built for Developers We love tools that get out of the way. Enjoy real-time Kanban boards, Markdown everywhere, and keyboard shortcuts that let you fly through your work.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Think of CodeBake as a simple hierarchy:

Account (Your Organization)
  └── Projects (Your Initiatives)
      └── Phases (Milestones)
          └── Tasks (The Work)

Projects move through Phases, and tasks flow through statuses: TODO → IN_PROGRESS → REVIEW → DONE. Simple, right?

docs.title: Ready to Dive In?
docs.text:
1. Sign up for your account.
  2. Create your first project
  3. Add some tasks to your board.
  4. Connect your AI assistant (this is where it gets fun!).

If you get stuck or just want to say hi:

docs.title: Core Concepts
docs.text: Understanding how CodeBake is organized will help you get the most out of it. Don't worry, it's pretty straightforward!

docs.title: How We Organize Things
docs.text:
CodeBake uses a simple hierarchy to keep your work tidy:

Accounts
  └── Projects
       └── Phases
            └── Tasks

docs.title: Accounts
docs.text: Think of an Account as your company or organization's headquarters. It holds all your team members and projects. You can belong to multiple accounts (like a personal one and a work one), but they are completely separate.

docs.title: Projects
docs.text: A Project is a specific initiative you're working on, like "Mobile App Launch" or "Website Redesign." - Each project has a unique Task Prefix (like APP or WEB) so you can easily identify tasks (e.g., APP-101). - Projects move through statuses like Active or Completed so you know what's currently in flight.

docs.title: Phases
docs.text: Phases are the milestones or stages of your project. We're framework-agnostic, so you can call them whatever you want—Sprints, Blocks, Milestones, or Versions. - Only one phase is Active at a time. This helps your team focus on what matters now. - When you finish a phase, the board clears off the completed tasks and brings in the next set. It's a great feeling!

docs.title: Tasks
docs.text: Tasks are the actual units of work. - They live on your board and move through statuses: Todo → In Progress → Review → Done. - You can assign them to people, add labels, and attach files. - If a task is too big, you can break it down into Subtasks (like APP-101a).

docs.title: The Workflow
docs.text:
We are a little dogmatic about statuses. After years of trying every complex workflow under the sun, we've found that the simplest solution is usually the best. You really only need 6 statuses:

  1. TODO: Ready to be picked up.
  2. IN-PROGRESS: Someone is working on it right now.
  3. REVIEW: The work is done and needs a second pair of eyes.
  4. BLOCKED: Stuck? Let your team know you need help.
  5. CANCELLED: Sometimes plans change, and that's okay.
  6. DONE: Finished and shipped!

This simplicity keeps everyone aligned without over-engineering the process.

docs.title: Real-Time Collaboration
docs.text: Everything in CodeBake updates instantly. If your teammate moves a card, you see it move. No refreshing required.

docs.title: Activity Summaries
docs.text: Keep your Project Managers and Clients happy without the constant status meetings. The Activity Summary shows exactly what's been happening on a project at any time, giving stakeholders peace of mind and total visibility.

docs.title: Meeting Mode
docs.text: We have specialized views designed specifically for online meetings. They help you go over tasks and prioritize them quickly, so you can spend less time talking about work and more time doing it.

docs.title: Markdown Everywhere
docs.text: We know developers love Markdown. You can use it in task descriptions, comments, and even this wiki!

docs.title: AI Integration
docs.text: This is our secret sauce. CodeBake is designed to be used by both humans and AI agents. - MCP Tools: Your AI assistant can read and write to your project. - Status Updates: Your AI can automatically move tasks for you as you work.

docs.title: Roles & Permissions
docs.text:
• Account Members: People who are part of your organization.
  • Project Members: People who have access to a specific project.
  • Guests: You can add an unlimited number of guests to your project. This is perfect for keeping clients up to date—they can view status and add issues, but won't mess up your board.
  • Owners: The folks who can change settings and manage the team.

docs.title: A Few Tips for Success
docs.text:
• Keep Phases Small: It feels better to complete phases often than to be stuck in one forever.
  • Use meaningful prefixes: API is better than PROJ1.
  • Let AI help: Don't manually update everything—ask your AI assistant to "move task 123 to review."

docs.title: Getting Started with CodeBake
docs.text: Welcome to CodeBake! We're excited to help you manage your projects more effectively. This guide will walk you through setting up your account and getting your first project off the ground.

docs.title: 1. Create Your Account
docs.text:
First things first, let's get you signed up.

  1. Head over to https://app.codebake.ai.
  2. Click Sign Up.
  3. Enter your email or choose a sign-in provider.
  4. You'll be asked to name your Account or Organization. This is the home for all your projects, so choose something that represents you or your team!

docs.title: 2. Create Your First Project
docs.text:
Now that you're in, let's create a space for your work.

  1. Click the New Project button on your dashboard.
  2. Give your project a Name (e.g., "Website Redesign").
  3. Choose a Task Prefix (e.g., "WEB"). This is a short code that will appear on all your tasks (like WEB-1, WEB-2). It helps keep things distinct.
  4. Click Create Project.

docs.title: 3. Invite Your Team
docs.text:
CodeBake is better together. Let's bring your team on board.

  1. Go to Settings > Members.
  2. Type in the email addresses of the people you want to invite.
  3. Choose their role (Member or Admin).
  4. Hit send! They'll get an email inviting them to join.

docs.title: 4. Connect Your AI Assistant
docs.text:
This is the best part. CodeBake is built to work with your AI tools.

  1. Navigate to your project settings.
  2. Follow the simple instructions to connect your preferred AI assistant (like AugmentCode, Cursor, or Zed) using MCP.
  3. Once connected, your AI becomes a superpower—it can create tasks, update statuses, and answer questions about your project context.

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
You're all set up! Here are a few things you might want to explore next:

  • Learn about our Core Concepts to understand how we organize work.
  • Check out MCP Tools to see exactly what your AI assistant can do.

docs.title: MCP Tools
docs.text:
Supercharge Your Workflow with AI

CodeBake supports the Model Context Protocol (MCP), which is a fancy way of saying we let your AI assistant talk directly to your project board. This is where the magic happens.

docs.title: What Does This Mean for You?
docs.text:
It means you can say goodbye to manual status updates. Instead of breaking your flow to alt-tab to a browser and move a ticket, you can just tell your AI (like Cursor or Zed) what you're doing, and it handles the paperwork. Engineers save hours every week by letting the AI manage the board.

Note: You don't need to configure any JSON or write any code to make this work. Your AI assistant is already trained to use these tools. You just need to connect them.

docs.title: What Your AI Can Do
docs.text: Once connected, your AI assistant becomes a full member of your team. It can:

docs.title: 📋 Manage Your Projects
docs.text:
• Find things: "What projects am I working on?"
  • Get context: "What's the current phase of the website redesign?"

docs.title: ✅ Handle Tasks
docs.text:
• Create tasks: "Add a task to fix the login bug."
  • Update status: "Mark task WEB-123 as done."
  • Find work: "What tasks are assigned to me?"
  • Move things along: "Mark this task as completed."
    • which automatically adds a comment to the task of what was done
    • and marks it as ready for review

docs.title: 💬 Collaborate
docs.text:
• Read comments: "What did Sarah say about this ticket?"
  • Add notes: "Add a comment that I'm investigating the API response."

docs.title: How to Use It
docs.text:
1. Connect: Go to your project settings and follow the steps to link your AI assistant.
  2. Chat: Just talk to your AI like you would a teammate.

docs.title: Try saying things like:
docs.text:
• "What's on my plate today?"
  • "Create a new task for the payment integration."
  • "I finished WEB-42, move it to review."
  • "Summarize the open tasks in this phase."

It's that simple. Happy coding!
